render.tex: \title{Relation Types } \\ %text Meaning of Reflexive, Transitive, Symmetric and Equivalence relations %

reason.tex: %text Best if we just took some examples before reading any definitions. Given a set $A = \left\lbrace 1,2,3\right\rbrace$, let us define the following relations % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNN} \hline & \text{Definition} & \text{Will give} \\ \hline R_1 & \left\lbrace (a,b): a \leq b\right\rbrace & \left\lbrace (1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(2,2), (2,3), (3,3)\right\rbrace \\ \hline R_2 & \left\lbrace (a,b): a = b \right\rbrace & \left\lbrace (1,1),(2,2), (3,3)\right\rbrace \\ \hline R_3 & \left\lbrace (a,b): a \geq b\right\rbrace & \left\lbrace (1,1), (2,1), (2,2), (3,1), (3,2), (3,3) \right\rbrace\\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} \\ %text The three relations have also been classified below. As you read the table, remember the definitions above % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{lMNNN} \hline \text{Type} & \text{Meaning} & R_1 & R_2 & R_3 \\ \hline \text{Reflexive} & (a,a)\in R\text{ for all } a & ✓ & ✓ & ✓ \\ \hline \text{Symmetric} & (a,b)\in R\implies (b,a)\in R & X & ✓ & X \\ \hline \text{Transitive} & (a,b), (b,c)\in R \implies (a,c)\in R & ✓ & ✓ & ✓ \\ \hline \text{Equivalence} & \text{Is all three of the above} & X & ✓ & X \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align}
